facts.text: The appellant Kajori Lal Agarwal was the owner-in-khas of 37.85 acres of land in Mouza Shibnath Das J. L. No. 110 and Mouza Kholai Singh J. L. No. 112 in Siliguri Town in the district of Darjeeling.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Kajori Lal Agarwal was the owner-in-khas of 37.85 acres of land in Mouza Shibnath Das J. L. No. 110 and Mouza Kholai Singh J. L. No. 112 in Siliguri Town in the district of Darjeeling.

facts.text: The said lands were acquired by the Union of India and the State of West Bengal under the West Bengal Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948 (No. 2 of 1948) for the Assam Rail Link Project.

anchor.surface_text: The said lands were acquired by the Union of India, and the State of West Bengal, respondents 1 & 2 respectively, under the relevant provisions of the West Bengal Land  Requisition and Acquisition  Act, 1948  No 2 of 1948   hereinafter called the Act  for the Assam Rail Link Project.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 is the Land Acquisition Officer, Darjeeling.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3 is the Land Acquisition Officer, Darjeeling.

facts.text: In those proceedings, the appellant claimed compensation at a flat rate of Rs. 100 per cottah amounting to Rs. 2,27,100.

anchor.surface_text: In those proceedings, the appellant claimed companypensation at a flat rate of Rs. 100 per companytah amounting to Rs. 2,27,100.

facts.text: The appellant also put in a claim for Rs. 8,000 on account of the severance and other grounds.

anchor.surface_text: He also put in a claim for Rs. 8,000 on account of the severance and other grounds.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 made an award under s. 7 of the Act on the 5th February, 1951 directing the payment of Rs. 22,074 to the appellant in lieu of his lands at the rate of Rs. 600 per acre.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3 made an award under s. 7 of the Act on the 5th February, 1951 directing the payment of Rs. 22,074 to the appellant in lieu of his lands at the rate of Rs. 600 per acre.

facts.text: After the award was pronounced, a notice was served on the appellant under s. 12(2) of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894.

anchor.surface_text: After the award was pronounced, a numberice was served on the appellant under s. 12 2  of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894  No. 1 of 1894   hereinafter called the Central Act .

facts.text: On the 21st March, 1951, the appellant accepted the said amount as compensation money under protest.

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st March, 1951, the appellant accepted the said amount as companypensation money under protest.

facts.text: The appellant filed an application before respondent No. 3 on the 2nd February, 1953 claiming that a reference should be made to the Court under s. 8 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant filed an application before respondent No. 3 on the 2nd February, 1953 and claimed that a reference should be made by him to the Court for decision of his claim for a larger amount of companypensation under s. 8 of the Act.

facts.text: The appellant alleged that the amount awarded was grossly inadequate having regard to the market value.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleged in his application that having regard to the market value of the land at the relevant time, the amount awarded to him by respondent No. 3 was grossly inadequate.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 rejected the appellant's application for reference on the ground that it was barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3 rejected the appellants application for reference on the ground that it was barred by time.

facts.text: The appellant challenged the validity of this order by moving the Calcutta High Court in Civil Revision Case No. 676 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the validity of this order by moving the Calcutta High Court in its revisional jurisdiction  Civil Revision Case No. 676 of 1954 .

facts.text: On the 16th June, 1955, a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court allowed the appellant's revisional application and remanded the case to respondent No. 3.

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th June, 1955, a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court allowed the appellants revisional application and sent the case to respondent No. 3 with a direction that the appellants application for reference should be dealt with in accordance with law.

facts.text: The High Court observed that though no limitation had been prescribed, an application must be made within a reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: In remitting the case to respondent No. 3, the High Court observed that though, in its opinion, numberlimitation had been prescribed for making an application for reference, such an application must nevertheless be made within a reasonable time.

facts.text: After remand, respondent No. 3 received an affidavit from the appellant on the 27th August, 1956 explaining the delay.

anchor.surface_text: After the appellants application was thus remanded to respondent No. 3, he filed an affidavit on the 27th August, 1956 and explained in detail the reasons for the delay made by him in filing his application for reference.

facts.text: On the 10th September, 1956, respondent No. 3 rejected the appellant's application on the ground that he had neglected to move for reference within a reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: On the 10th September, 1956 respondent No. 3 rejected the appellants application on the ground that he had neglected to move for reference within a reasonable time.

facts.text: The appellant challenged this order by moving the Calcutta High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution read with s. 115 CPC in Civil Rule No. 3886 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by the appellant again by moving the Calcutta High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution read with s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure  Civil Rule No. 3886 of 1956 .

facts.text: On the 6th July, 1959, a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court dismissed the appellant's application.

anchor.surface_text: On the 6th July, 1959, this case was heard by a Division Bench of the said High Court and the application made by the appellant was dismissed on the ground that the High Court saw numberreason to interfere with the order passed by respondent No. 3.

facts.text: The appellant appealed to this Court (Supreme Court) by special leave in Civil Appeal No. 666 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 666 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated July 6, 1959 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 3886 of 1956.

facts.text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Anoop Singh contends that the High Court erred and relies on the Calcutta High Court ruling in Birendra Nath Ray Sarkar v. Union of India on 12th January, 1953 that there was no prescribed period of limitation under s.8.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Anoop Singh companytends that the High Court was in error in number reversing the decision of respondent No. 3 and in support of his argument, he has relied on the fact that on the 12th January, 1953, the Calcutta High Court had ruled in the case of Birendra Nath Ray Sarkar Another v. Union of India Another  2   Civil Rule No. 2940 of 1951  that there was numberprescribed period of limitation for an application for reference under s. 8 of the Act

facts.text: The appellant was advised to make his application for reference only after knowing about the Birendra Nath decision.

anchor.surface_text: , and it was only after the appellant knew about this decision that he was advised to make his present application for reference.

facts.text: Section 8(2) of the Act was amended by Act VIII of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that presumably as a result of the decision of the Calcutta High Court, s. 8  2  of the Act has been amended by Act VIII of 1954.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that the appellant's application on 2nd February, 1953 was barred by time under s.8(2) read with s.18(2) of the Central Act.

anchor.surface_text: Since we hold that the application originally made by the appellant to respondent No. 3 under s. 8 1  of the Act on the 2nd February, 1953 for reference, was barred by time

facts.text: The appeal fails and the order passed by the High Court is confirmed, though on different grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails, and the order passed by the High Court is companyfirmed, though on different grounds.

This order was challenged by the appellant again by moving the Calcutta High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution read with s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure  Civil Rule No. 3886 of 1956 .

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 of the Central Act reads thus 18.  1  Any person interested who has number accepted the award may, by written application to the Collector, require that the matter be referred by the Collector for the determination of the Court, whether his objection be to the measurement of the land, the amount of the companypensation, the persons to whom it is payable, or the apportionment of the companypensation among the persons interested The a application shall state the grounds on which objection to the award is taken  a  if the person making it was present or represented before the Collector at the time when he made his award, within six weeks from the date of the Collectors award  b  in other cases, within six weeks of the receipt of the numberice from the Collector under section 12, subsection  2 , or within six months from the date of the Collectors award, whichever period shall first expire.

arguments.claim: No limitation prescribed for application for reference under s.8, but must be made within reasonable time

anchor.surface_text: In remitting the case to respondent No. 3, the High Court observed that though, in its opinion, no limitation had been prescribed for making an application for reference, such an application must nevertheless be made within a reasonable time. On that view, the High Court left it to respondent No. 3 to consider whether the appellant had moved for reference within a reasonable time vide Kajori Lal Agarwal v. The Union of India Ors.  1 .

anchor.surface_text: On the 6th July, 1959, this case was heard by a Division Bench of the said High Court and the application made by the appellant was dismissed on the ground that the High Court saw no reason to interfere with the order passed by respondent No. 3.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . The result is, the appeal fails, and the order passed by the High Court is companyfirmed, though on different grounds.

arguments.court_reasoning: Order confirmed though on different grounds

arguments.claim: High Court erred in not reversing LAO's decision; no prescribed limitation under s.8 per Birendra Nath precedent; delay because advised only after knowing that decision

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Anoop Singh contends that the High Court was in error in not reversing the decision of respondent No. 3 and in support of his argument, he has relied on the fact that on the 12th January, 1953, the Calcutta High Court had ruled in the case of Birendra Nath Ray Sarkar Another v. Union of India Another  2   Civil Rule No. 2940 of 1951  that there was no prescribed period of limitation for an application for reference under s. 8 of the Act, and it was only after the appellant knew about this decision that he was advised to make his present application for reference. Mr. Anoop Singh argues that this fact should have been taken into account by the Calcutta High Court

court_response_anchor.surface_text: February, 1953 for reference, was barred by time, it is number necessary to companysider the appellants plea whether it was made within a reasonable t

arguments.court_reasoning: Limitation applies under s.8(2) read with s.18(2) Central Act; no need to consider reasonable time or explanations

arguments.claim: s.8(2) makes Central Act provisions apply mutatis mutandis only after reference is made, not to application stage; thus no limitation for application under s.8(1)

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta High Court has held that the effect of the provisions prescribed by this sub-section is to make the relevant provisions of the Central Act applicable to proceedings subsequent to the making of the reference. This view proceeds on the basis that when sub-s.  2  refers to any reference made to the Court, it emphasises the fact that up to the making of the reference the provisions of the Central Act have no application... One cannot extend backwards the said provisions. That is how the matter has been succinctly put by the High Court in holding that the period of limitation prescribed by s. 18  2  of the Central Act cannot apply to an application for reference made under s. 8 1  of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: evant provisions of the Central Act in relation to all proceedings which take place prior to the making of the reference. When a reference has been ma

arguments.court_reasoning: Clause covers proposed/intended references; scheme includes application stage

arguments.claim: s.8(2) 'in respect of any reference made to the Court' means provisions apply to proposed/intended applications for reference, including limitation under s.18(2) Central Act

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error in reading the clause in respect of any reference made to the Court in s. 8  2  of the Act as referring to cases where reference has already been made. In the context, what the clause means is that the provisions of the Central Act shall mutatis mutandis apply in respect. of any reference intended, proposed, or asked, to be made, and not in respect of any reference already made.

arguments.claim: Scheme of s.8 and Act requires Central Act provisions from s.18 onwards to apply from application stage; unreasonable to apply only post-reference

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the scheme of s. 8, considered in the light of the other provisions of the Act, it seems to us clear that the object of the Legislature in making the relevant provisions of the Central Act applicable to references was to take in all the relevant provisions of the Central Act which had reference to the making of reference and naturally, these provisions would begin with s.18 of the Central Act which is the first section in Part III of the Central Act dealing with reference to Court and procedure thereon. It would,. we think, be unreasonable to hold that until a reference in made, the said provisions do not apply and it is only after the reference is made that the said provisions begin to operate.

arguments.claim: Mandatory 'shall refer' in s.8(1) does not exclude application of limitation, similar to s.18(1) Central Act

anchor.surface_text: It is true that S. 8 1  of the Act uses the mandatory words the Collector shall refer the matter to the decision of the Court but that does not mean that it necessarily excludes the application of the provision as to limitation. Section 18 1  of the Central Act, though somewhat differently worded, has in law the same effect... The position with regard to the mandatory provision contained in s. 8 1  of the Act is exactly similar.

arguments.claim: Legislature unlikely to allow applications at any time (sweet will); would cause anomalies; no need for reasonable time doctrine

anchor.surface_text: On principle, it seems extremely unlikely that the Act which deals with acquisition and requisition of properties, could have intended to leave it to the sweet-will of the parties to make an application for reference at any time they like. The High Court no doubt realised the anomalies which would result in adopting such a construction... In, our opinion, it is unnecessary to invoke such a general consideration, because s. 8 2  of the Act, in terms, makes s. 18 2  of the Central Act applicable, and there is no occasion to consider whether a particular application has been made within a reasonable time or no.

arguments.claim: 1954 amendment to s.8(2) expressly including s.18(2) supports that limitation always applied; same clause shows consistent interpretation

anchor.surface_text: It appears that presumably as a result of the decision of the Calcutta High Court, s. 8  2  of the Act has been amended by Act VIII of 1954. The amended provision reads. thus - 8.  2  The provisions of sub-section  2  of section 18... shall, so far as they may be applicable, apply in respect of any reference made to the Court under sub- section  1 . ... This amended provision lends support to the view that the clause in respect of any reference made to the Court does not mean that the provisions have to apply after such a reference is made, but that it includes all cases where reference is intended, or proposed, or asked, to be made

arguments.claim: Appellant's application of 2 Feb 1953 barred by limitation under s.8(2) + s.18(2) Central Act; no need to consider reasonable time

anchor.surface_text: Since we hold that the application originally made by the appellant to respondent No. 3 under s. 8 1  of the Act on the 2nd February, 1953 for reference, was barred by time... Section 8 2  of the Act read with S. 18 2  of the Central Act specifically prescribes limitation for the making of such applications and there is no doubt that having regard to the said provisions, the appellants application is barred by time.

holdings.text: The Calcutta High Court erred in holding that no period of limitation is prescribed by S. 8 of the Act for making an application for reference; S.8(2) mutatis mutandis applies provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 including the limitation under S.18(2) to applications for reference under S.8(1).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error in reading the clause in respect of any reference made to the Court in s. 8  2  of the Act as referring to cases where reference has already been made. In the context, what the clause means is that the provisions of the Central Act shall mutatis mutandis apply in respect. of any reference intended, proposed, or asked, to be made, and not in respect of any reference already made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of 'in respect of any reference made' includes proposed/intended references; scheme of S.8 incorporates LA Act from application stage; mandatory 'shall refer' subject to limitation like S.18(1) LA Act; policy against unlimited applications; 1954 amendment confirms interpretation.

holdings.text: The appellant's application to the Collector under S.8(1) of the Act on 2nd February 1953 for reference was barred by limitation under S.8(2) read with S.18(2) of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894.

anchor.surface_text: Since we hold that the application originally made by the appellant to respondent No. 3 under s. 8 1  of the Act on the 2nd February, 1953 for reference, was barred by time... Section 8 2  of the Act read with S. 18 2  of the Central Act specifically prescribes limitation for the making of such applications and there is no doubt that having regard to the said provisions, the appellants application is barred by time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application made beyond 6 weeks from receipt of notice under S.12(2) LA Act on 21 March 1951 and beyond 6 months from award on 5 February 1951.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to consider whether the appellant's application was made within a reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: Since we hold that the application originally made by the appellant to respondent No. 3 under s. 8 1  of the Act on the 2nd February, 1953 for reference, was barred by time, it is not necessary to consider the appellants plea whether it was made within a reasonable time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory limitation under S.8(2) + S.18(2) LA Act applies, superseding need for reasonable time doctrine.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and the order passed by the High Court is confirmed, though on different grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails, and the order passed by the High Court is confirmed, though on different grounds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application barred by limitation; High Court correct in result despite erroneous reasoning on limitation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error in reading the clause in respect of any reference made to the Court in s. 8  2  of the Act as referring to cases where reference has already been made. In the context, what the clause means is that the provisions of the Central Act shall mutatis mutandis apply in respect. of any reference intended, proposed, or asked, to be made, and not in respect of any reference already made.
The result is, the appeal fails, and the order passed by the High Court is companyfirmed, though on different grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Since we hold that the application originally made by the appellant to respondent No. 3 under s. 8 1  of the Act on the 2nd February, 1953 for reference, was barred by time... Section 8 2  of the Act read with S. 18 2  of the Central Act specifically prescribes limitation for the making of such applications and there is no doubt that having regard to the said provisions, the appellants application is barred by time.
The result is, the appeal fails, and the order passed by the High Court is companyfirmed, though on different grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Since we hold that the application originally made by the appellant to respondent No. 3 under s. 8 1  of the Act on the 2nd February, 1953 for reference, was barred by time, it is not necessary to consider the appellants plea whether it was made within a reasonable time.
The result is, the appeal fails, and the order passed by the High Court is companyfirmed, though on different grounds.
The result is, the appeal fails, and the order passed by the High Court is companyfirmed, though on different grounds.
